Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 02:12PM easyquilts wrote: HI....I have the same diagnosis, and am just finishing up rads....My BS told me that it was a must after my lumpectomy....I had no real qualms about it....I wanted to do all I could to rid myself of my cancer...When my rads are over, I will have only a five-percent chance of a recurrence.  I will not be taking Tam.....It's contraindicated for me. Good luck to you..... Sandy
Posts.Title: Rads for low-grade DCIS redheadace1 fullofquestions

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 07:47AM easyquilts wrote: I don't know if this will help anyone, but to tell the truth decidiing to do radiation was't a big deal for me....It was reccommended to me by my BS, and the rad/oncologist I consulted with thought ti would be beneficial....In fact, he told me that the only bc patients who should not consider rads are the ones who have had a mastectmy...I asked..... Anyway, I chose to do rads because I wanted to do as much as I possibly could to irradicate this horrible cancer from my body....Every time I was on that table, I envisioned stray cancer cells being burnt to a crisp!  That brought me comfort. And....I breezed through radiation....I finished this past Monday, and I'm doing OK.  I do have some fatigue, and itching...skin is still discolored...but I have to admit that the experience was not a bad one for me.  I had caring techs and nurses, and a great doctor..I saw him once a week, and he was always pleased with how my body was responding to the treatments. When we decided on a lumpectomy....the DCIS was small, unifocal and easy to see, since I do not have dense breasts.....we also knew that rads would follow.....While I was concerned about SE's, particularly fatigue and skin issues...I was willing to give it a try.....Since I cannot take Tamox, I knew radiation would be my only shot at preventing a recurrence.  So...Yes...I am glad I made the decision to do radiation for my very early stage breast cancer...I wanted to throw whatever I could at the monster that had invaded my life so unexpectedly.   Sandy
Posts.Title: Rads for low-grade DCIS redheadace1 fullofquestions

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2008 09:07AM easyquilts wrote: jlap...I agree with LJ13...Hit that sucker with all you've got!  You have an agressive caner...So...Be agressive against it... Sandy
Posts.Title: Thinking of not doing rads!!! nobleanna007 nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 08:29AM easyquilts wrote: Yeah...That not breathing thing..We all did it when we got those calls...It's awful..And you can't concentrate on listening to what whoever is calling is actually saying to you... This will be the worst time for you...Tests, waiting, the calls.  The whole thing is just awful, and the panic makes hard to cncentrate on anything....I was completely whacked out at work for at least the first two weeks after my DX...You just freak out...I'm better now, because I've had my lumpectomy and am soon having rads...You will feel better, too, once you have a game plan....You will be surprised at how much actually doing something will help. Good luck to you..Come here as often as you need to to talk....This forum is the best... Sandy
Posts.Title: Waiting Biopsy Carol315 leaf

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 03:33AM easyquilts wrote: Economom....The others are so right...This is the best place for you to be right now....You will find so much good information, and best of all lots of great support.... DO NOT worry about trying to stay positive...Just take things one day... sometimes one minute...at a time. You don' t have to prove anything to anybody...and you have a perfect right to your feelings..whatever they are.   This is the hardest part...When you first learn you have cancer, and do not know what is coming next.  Believe me, you will feel a lot better when you have a treatment plan....You will feel more in control.   Please don't hesitate to come here often....I'm so sorry you had to come here in the first place, but this is the best place you could possibly be....Ask any questions you might have...Someone will either know the answer, or where to look for it....We are a pretty close bunch, and we welcome you as a sister.   Blessings, Sandy
Posts.Title: Joining the boards econmom omo

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 02:35PM easyquilts wrote: Hi.....I'm keeping my fingers crosseed for a good report..whenever it comes!  I know how hard it is to wait for test results...We ALL know....It's the worst part of the whole experience...You just feel as if you are in limbo...Your world just stops.....So...Hang in there...The time will pass....slowly, for sure...but it will pass.  Try to keep yourself busy doing things you enjoy.   Sandy
Posts.Title: Just wondering if my wait will really be that long lexio lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 08:08PM easyquilts wrote: Jen...The waitng is so awful.....I remember not being able to function...Just ask my boss....The odds are greatly in your favor to have b-9 results, so keep that in mind...Alhtough I know you will still worry...I know I did..... Be sure to let us know how it turns out...We will be pulling for you! Sandy
Posts.Title: Scared to death JenP2008 BessB

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 09:23AM easyquilts wrote: Sallyl....Anne is right...Take a deep breath and try to take this one step at a time...Don't read too much online..except for this website, of course...the  information here is reliable.....And some of the dtudies are old, or done on very ffew people... This is the toughest part..The testing, waiting and decision making....Keep us posted....We will be right here for you.  Remember....You could very well fall into the percentage that is NOT cancer. God Bless, Sandy
Posts.Title: Pretty scared Triciaski vitaledoda

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 12:22PM easyquilts wrote: LB.....I'm so glad you got an earlier apponntment...The waiting is awful.... I had some Xanax too, and used it while I was waiting...and after the call that told me I had DCIS.  Taht was after a stereotactic biopsy that followed the two mammos.....Good stuff, that Xanax! I also took X before my biopsy and before my lulmpectomy.... Although I was ot part of the 80%, I was lucky in that my DCIS was amall, and that the cancer was found at such an early stage.....I had a lulmpectomy and six weeks of radiation treatments, and will have my followup mamogram on December 4th....I had..and still have...great doctors, (and other caretakers)  who have been a blessing to me, and have made t his journey as easy as t hey possibly could.... Please let us all know how t hings to tomorrow....Remember SOMEONE has to be in the 20%!!! It might as well be YOU...... God Bless, Sandy
Posts.Title: Please help, just joined LB2008 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 08:46PM easyquilts wrote: Kimberlyn...No...You are NOT alone, and that's a plus...for sure....We are all here for you...I was absollutely amazed by the behavior of that insensitive doctor.....You were so right to run away from him as fast as you could...What a jerk!  Remember this...You have the right to have copies of ALL of your medical data...including doctor's notes.  I have begun a file of my lab work, and will soon start one with notess..... Your DX is encouraging, and you do have time to get in with the right doctor (and team) for you.   Come here as often as you need to.....It's a great place to rant, cry, laugh, bitch and moan...You name it!  I don't know what i would have done without these wonderful people. Sandy from Cincinnati....AKA kermit

Posts.Title: Back on the Roller Coaster Sooner than I thought! julz4 leaf

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 10:18AM easyquilts wrote: BlueMama....I did not have to have chemo, because my cancer was not invaasive.  It was pure DCIS.  However, I have a friend who was also "borderline", and she decided to go ahead and have the chemo, just to be on the safe side.  Although it was entirely her decision...as yours must be.. her doctors did advise her to have the chemo...even though her dx was borderline for it.  I think I would have done the same thing...In fact, I know I would. You just have to weigh all the pros and cons, gather all the good information...talk things over with your doctors, and make your own mind up....It's your life! Sandy
Posts.Title: Borderline for Chemo BlueMama Cindy1960

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 05:07AM easyquilts wrote: Deb....What a terrible day you had!  I'm so sorry...It just seems as if it's too much sometimes.... I hope when you return you will get better care.....It's amazing how much better things go when techs and nurses are caring and listen.   God Bless, Sandy
Posts.Title: I broke down today Deb-from-Ohio Harley44

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 08:00AM easyquilts wrote: Tomatojuice.....That first day is hard on everyone! You just don't really know what to expect, and there you are, half naked....I was so lucky that my center has only women technicians..... That was so nice.  We became "friends", and they were wonderful. Things will get better as  you get used to the routine.....It will become a part of your day. At the same time, you will be so glad when that part of your day is over at the end of 29 visits! I had 28 treatments...no boosts.....and honestly, the time flew by. I had few SE's, to deal with,so that was a plus.  I am now 2 1/2 weeks out, and doing fine.  You will be fine, too!  Just hang in there.   The treatments themselves take such a little bit of time..I was usually in and out in ten to fifteen menutes...and on my way.  Sometimes I would plan a quilt during treatments, or just look at the beatiful picture of trees and skies that was in the huge overhead light (huge nine-patch). Good luck to you.Come here often and tell us how everything is going. Sandy
Posts.Title: Rads started today tomatojuice Linalee

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 08:32AM easyquilts wrote: Hi TJ......I know....Wanting your life back is so normal.....You just want to turn the clock back, don't you?  And yes, the whole thing does become your project...I quilt, so I know about that creative place not being so accesable.....Don't worry, though, it will come back.  Your creativity is a part of you that cannot be erased....Just think of it as taking a little break. Right now all your thoughts and energies are focused on getting well, and that is as it should be.  I have a friend who wasn't able to touch her quilting for months after her diagnosis, but is now back in teh swing of things.... How did your first treatment go?  After a while it will be routine, and the days will sail by.  You won't believe how fast the weeks go by....I'm three or four weeks out, and it seems like another me that did rads...I still can't believe I did that! My techs were all women, and they were wonderful!  I saw them all again yesterday, when I went in for a follow-up with my rad/oncol, and it was so nice to see them again. BTW...I turned 65 on September 11th...The day of your first treatment....Can't wrap my mind arond that at all....I had a great day, though, and feel good Got to go to work! Take care, and God Bless, Sandy

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 07:03AM easyquilts wrote: Hi Morning....I think you have expressed yourself very well, and that you have raised a valid concern. I know what you mean about getting to the point where you are thinking it really wasn't so bad, then panicing at the thought of a daughter being diagnosed with bc.....I have thought those thougths myself.  It's OK (in a way) for ME to have bc, but NOT my daughter or my sister.... The past four months have been challenging, to say the least....And I am finally nearing the end of my treatment.  I've done pretty well....But...I DO NOT want my daughter or sister to have the same eperience, no matter how well it went...No way. I belong to a small quilting group of about twenty women....FIVE of us have had breast cancer.  Two of us at the same time.  Amazing, isn't it?   Sandy

Posts.Title: Dear Lord, I just scheduled brain surgery AlaskaDeb heymoose

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 08:51AM easyquilts wrote: Ferretmom and Bren...Thanks for your reply....I am not fair-skinned...in fact, I tan, rather than burn, and the nurse/tech at the center told me that that was a good thing...I'm surprised to hear that the SE's can begin to show up so early....I've always heard that they take a couple of weeks to start...if you are gong to have them at all..... I work in a two preson offfice five hours a day, three days a week...Just my lady boss and me...I do have to go out into the building for various things...mail, large copy machine, getting supplies, etc., so I am wondering just how much I can get away with...I have bought some inexpensive cotton bras (Bestform) from Walmart, trading in my nice Bali ones I got on sale at Kohl's....Cotton is more absorbant....When I am at home, I don't wear a bra of any kind, and wear looose fitting or soft cotton tops.....I have been told I can use a special natural deoderant and Johonson's Baby Corstarch powder.  After i walk for an hour outside, I am careful to was with my Dove and apply some of the poweder under my breasts to abasorb any moisture... I have already decided that I will take time off from work if things get too bad..particularly the fatigue.  I am not a naturally energetic person...except in the mornings....so....Even though my job is only part time, I do get comp time, as well as disabilitiy pay (sick leave)....So...Hopefully, I won't lose much pay. Thanks again...If you can think of any hints i could use, let me know!   Sandy

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 09:09AM easyquilts wrote: HI...I was dx with DCIS last summer....I had a lumpectomy and six weeks of readiation treatments, and that was all...No adjunct therapy.  The reason for this is that one of the SE's of Tamoxifen is the possibility of blood clots.  I already take Plavix and a whole aspirin daily...Had a heart attack several years ago.  My breast surgeon was quilte adamant tha I not take Tamoxifen....She told me that the risks far outweighed the benefits for me.    I have a 5% chance of having a recurrence...which is pretty good...so I am comfortable with my decision. Hope this helps.  Sandy from Cincinnati

In a funny way, I do want some indication that the rads are working...Just not too much!  Does that sound nuts?  I'm not saying that I want a lot of nasty se's....it's just that I want to KNOW something is happening...But only a little... Just the word "cancer" is a terrible shock when it is applied to yourself...Everyone secretly dreads this horrible disease. But....This is the absolutely best place to come to vent, ask questions, gather information, and recieve loving suppot. The women here are smart, compassionate and knowledgeable.  They...we...will walk this journey with you! Keep us posted as to what is going on with you. Sandy

Posts.Title: How Early can SE's begin? easyquilts AccidentalTourist

Posts.Content: easyquilts wrote: Hi Everyone....Back in May, I came here asking if I should actually walk in the Relay I was working in....A couple of you asked that I tell you if I walked, and how it was... I actually had to miss the first Survivor's Walk....but...Came back later....I decided to join the walkers..started, and looked up to see my husband coming toward me...He had his matching Survivor's T on...We took that First Walk together....I think we both cried. As we walked, and looked at the luminaries that would be lit later, we had a surprise.  We found one with my name on it....For some reason that stopped me cold....It was a sort of reality check....Yes, I have had Breast Cancer...Yes, I did have a lumpectomy and six weeks of rads...Yes, I am now a Cancer Survivor..... Later on, when the luminaries were lit....and those who were there to honor wives and husbands were asked to come light their candles, I was absolutely overwhelmed with something I can't name when my husband of over 41 years went up to light his candle in my  honor....Makes me tear up even now. So....Walk if you get a chance...It will change something in you....No matter if you had/have DCIS or any other variety of BC.....You are a survivor....You have faced the enemy and won....You are alive! Sandy Sandy from Cincinanti....AKA Kermit Dx 5/21/2008, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 1, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Hang in there! Samdy
Posts.Title: How Early can SE's begin? easyquilts AccidentalTourist

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 12:44PM easyquilts wrote: Julie...Thanks so much for your sweet post...It meant a  lot to me. I actually meant to post this in the DCIS folder...Have asked the mods to do it for me, as I don't know how.... My husband hasn't always known just what to say to me, but when it all started, and he saw that I was barely functioning, he began to take over things in the house....He did what he could, and that was his way of "helping"..  Once, when I was particularly low, he told me that I was a stong woman....I was so surprised....I've never thought of myself that way, but evidently he did..and does.... Knowing this has been a real boost for me...and I think of it when I am feeling down or "weak".... Sandy
Posts.Title: First Walk easyquilts Mary22

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 12:54PM easyquilts wrote: You are one strong woman to have survived the past five years!  Oh my goodness.....You have been through the wringer, so to speak. Thankfully, your  tumor was so small....That is a real blessing. You are right at the hardest part of your journey...The Beginning.....I was where you are a bit over a year ago, and know how it feels to not know what is what...and what to do about it.... Take a few deep breaths and tell yourself that this too will pass, and that you can do whatever you have to.....We women are strong.... You are so fortunate to have found this board....The women here are wonderful, and many are very knowledgeable....You will get LOTS of love and support here...I know I did....It's so important to have that kind of support..especially in the beginning....When you are feeling so confused and completely whacked out....(at least I felf whacked out!)..... Hang in there...There will certainly be a light at the end of this particular tunnel...And...You are definitely not alone! Sandy

Blessings to You, Sandy

Posts.Title: Life sentence, even with no cancer? theonlyfalco AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 02:39AM easyquilts wrote: I read a lot, and am a quilter....My username is "easyquilts" because I only do easy stuff....I make up for it by using great fabrics and wonderful colors.  I usually have not real idea of how a quilt will turn out, so I am usaully surprised...Sometimes for the good, and smetimes for the bad....I love to buy fabrics, so it is always a treat to visit a good quilt shop or fabric store....My big problem is making myaslf actually finish my quilts....Once I have mulled over the design and fabrics, and have made the quilt top, I often get stuck.  The rest...sandwiching, quilting and biniding are work....I love the creative process of choosing a pattern...I treat pattterns as "suggestions"...., shopping for fabrics, cutting out and stitching the top...is fn.  Thanks for a great topic! Sandy

Being told you have breast cancer takes your breat away...Nothing is the same after that... But, you have found the best place to be....As someone else has said, the sisters here are awesome, and you will be supported every step of the way....Coming here has certainly been a blessing for me..and for so many others.... Come here often, and ask any quetions you might have...I know the wealth of information out there can b overwhelming....And, I know it all seems to be unreal now....I've known I had BC since May 21st, and I still can't wrap my mind around it....How can this be?  I've already had a heart attack.... Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 09:57AM easyquilts wrote: I use a Vitamin E cream, and if I am itchy, I use the Eucerin Calming Lotion.....The Vitamin E cream is feels really nice, and is helping to reduce  my lumpectomy scar....I keep the Eucerin Calming Cream in my bad..but forgot it this morning!  Sandy
Posts.Title: Skin care AFTER Radiation & THE SUN? Krissy37 Krissy37

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 02:56PM easyquilts wrote: Hi justkat....You are right....Once you have your treatment plan underway, you will feel so much better....Partly because you are finally DOING SOMETHING, and partly because you will have something constructive to focus on..... We have all been through what you are experiencing...The fear of the unknown is so strong, and so destructive....Tears, depresssion, anger...You name it.....It'a all there.. You can count on the ladies here to be with you throughout your journey...We will try to answer any questions you may have about your treatment (or anything else), and will be here to "hold" you when you need to vent.....Many of the ladies are very knowledgeable re. breast cancer, so you will get a lot of good information, too...and the site is great.....There is so much good informaion here.  Finding out you have breast cancer....no matter what the type, stage or grade is devastating   No one ever really thinks it will happen to them....I know I was completely blind-sided, and was in a fog for weeks....Just ask my long-suffering boss! All that you are experiencing is totally normal, and to be expected....After all, you have just recieved a body blow!  It's like being sucker-punched by a ghorilla!!!  The idea is to come up fighting!  And you will... We are so sorry you are here, but want you to know that you need not feel alone...Just come here.  Read, gather information, and ask questions.....And just hang out with us! i don't know your husband, but I am betting that he will not allow your diagnosis to damage your relationship...as you fear.  My own husband is somewhat clueless re. medical things, but he has been a true support...We have been married over forty years, so it would take a lot more than breast cancer to make much difference!   jsut sit down with your husband and tell him how you feel....Share your fears and concerns about your cancer with him....That way, he will feel a part of what is going on....I have found that shairng my feelings with my husband has brought us closer together. We feel we are in this together. My husband has gone with me to all major appointments and procedures...Be sure to include yours in these things....He may not be totally comfortable, but he will go, and that will be a help to you both. Wishing you well....Cry when you want to....yell and scream when you need to...Throw things whenever the mood strikes!   Love and Hugs, Sandy

Posts.Title: Survivor vs. Surviving sdg605 heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 09:40PM easyquilts wrote: Judie....I think...from reading your post...that in your heart, you want to take this opportunity to once again have your own home...I say GO FOR IT, GIRL!!! Let me tell you a short story....I work for a non-profit that helps low to moderate income people buy their own homes...We provide a hand-up...not a handout....We do lots of education, down-payment assistance and help our clients secure good loans...It is all paid back...As I said, we provide a hand up, and that is so important. My point is that one of our clients is a 75 year old woman who is currently living with her daughter and SIL...She likes it there, but longs to be in her own home again..So...At 75, she is working with us to make that dream come true....Your story reminded me of Janet Grace.....She is going for it, and so should you...I think you would come to regret not taking this wonderful opportunity. Sandy

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 11:25AM easyquilts wrote: HI....I did a six week program of radiation therapy....The radiated breast is noticeably smaller than the other one....It began to shrink during the treatment.....  My rad/oncol. did not want me to use any creams or lotions, etc., unless I needed them.  Fortunately, I never really did....I onlly used Aloe Vera a couple of times to cool things down.   I had an easy time of it....No burns, weepy skin, etc...Just pinkness, a little itchiness and once in a while a sense of warmth.....Not bad. Sandy

So....Enjoy! Sandy
